results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 30]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

In this film, Wallace focuses on Australian birdlife, particularly waterbirds filmed from a small boat among lily pads and overhanging trees on still waterways located in the Northern Territory of Australia.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’ (dramatically placed over a crocodile with jaws raised and open), ‘Wild Paradise’
00:00:18:00 a close-up of bougainvillea, some men in shorts look nervously at the camera and cormorants (water birds) stand among water lilies and reeds
00:00:49:00 the men take to the water in a small fishing boat with outboard motor and pass by some waterbirds including cormorants, a large pelican, white egrets
00:02:01:00 the boat passes a flock of magpie geese followed by more pelicans, storks and black ibis
00:02:38:00 a white bellied sea eagle perched in a tree
00:02:48:00 some spoonbill and other water birds
00:04:05:00 a large black necked stork takes off in flight
00:04:13:00 a pelican stands with a chick close by
00:04:45:00 views around the river and wetlands
00:05:26:00 a lone magpie goose stands at the water and a few white egrets in flight
00:06:10:00 a darter water bird perched in a tree
00:06:23:00 an eagle on the very top of a tree
00:06:43:00 a large pelican sitting among lily pads
00:06:48:00 the sightseers on their boat
00:08:19:00 campsite alongside the river
00:09:44:00 water buffalo, dirt roads and flowering trees
00:10:50:00 irrigation in a banana tree plantation
00:11:09:00 a tourist bus on a dusty road
00:11:46:00 what appears to be an old ‘fan boat’ for skimming over swamps and wetlands
00:12:23:00 a black and white heron looking for dinner in the water
00:14:47:00 vehicles on a road leading into a town
00:15:11:00 driving into Darwin
00:15:49:00 the ‘Paspalis Centrepoint’ building in Darwin
00:15:54:00 a banner across the road for a concert featuring ‘Australian Crawl’ and ‘John Farnham’

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 24]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film captures a group walking trip by members of the ‘Walkabouters’ club to the Grampians (Gariwerd) in Victoria. It features the making of a ‘pit oven’ style barbeque and showcases the walking to be had by visitors through the many ravines and paths but also the grandeur of the sweeping views from what can seem like perilous pinnacles and lookouts.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 title cards ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘The Dreaming Place’, ‘A WHC Film’
00:00:38:00 views of the Grampians range off in the distance
00:00:56:00 driving through a small township
00:02:51:00 creating a ‘pit oven’ by setting a fire in a deep hole in the ground
00:02:59:00 stones are thrown into the flames and then covered with pieces of terracotta tiles on which meat in aluminium foil is placed for cooking
00:03:38:00 the pit is covered with a piece of metal, hessian bags, stones and dirt
00:04:15:00 a woman climber is helped to the top of some rocks
00:06:10:00 cars driving along a dirt road in the bush
00:06:44:00 an example of the the beautiful rock of the Grampians
00:07:07:00 sign for ‘Forest Commision of Victoria’ ‘Camp of the Emu’s Foot’
00:07:15:00 Indigenous art on rock walls
00:09:48:00 a still river which runs under a wooden walk bridge among tall reeds
00:10:19:00 a fenced off shallow cavern possibly with Indigenous drawings on the rock
00:10:35:00 views of Indigenous drawings up close
00:11:07:00 driving through the bush
00:11:54:00 grey patchy granite rock of the Grampians
00:12:29:00 a lone walker stands on top of a high peak
00:15:25:00 walking through the bush
00:17:00:00 groups of kangaroos and emus
00:18:23:00 climbing a steep ravine
00:20:19:00 sitting on a precipice overlooking the dramatic scenery below
00:20:43:00 a large body of water, possibly Lake Fyans in the Grampians
00:23:22:00 walking along narrow pathways through the bush
00:24:14:00 sign ‘Grand Canyon’
00:25:43:00 sign ‘Echo Cave’ which appears to be painted on the rock itself
00:26:13:00 another sign ‘Pinnacle Street’ painted on a path rock
00:26:24:00 a rock worn away into the shape of a mushroom
00:26:49:00 sign ‘Silent Street’
00:28:12:00 walkers at a pinnacle lookout showing the fencing used for safety in the Grampians

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 13]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film captures Mount Buller and surrounds, in Victoria during the summer period. There are views of the mountains, trees and wildflowers, a river and people walking and picnicking.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:45:00 cut logs on a truck.
00:03:26:00 walkers reach the Mount Buller summit.
00:07:27:00 walkers scrambling through bush and fallen trees.
00:07:51:00 several women sitting on a large log.
00:10:34:00 people walking through very tall trees show the scale of the trees growth.
00:10:55:00 a river view through the mountain landscape.
00:11:22:00 roadside picnic.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 15]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is made up of two films. The first captures the dramatic coastline of the ‘Shipwreck Coast’ in the west of Victoria. It also features the ‘Fletcher Jones’ (clothing manufacturers) at Warrnambool including the ‘Silver Ball’ water tower designed by Ralph Jones, engineer and eldest son of owner David Fletcher Jones. Erected in 1967 as part of the Pleasant Hill factory’s extensive fire protection system, the water tower was state heritage listed, along with other aspects of the Pleasant Hill site, in August 2006.

The second film features Victorian National parks.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 title ‘Coastal Panarama’ and ‘A WHC Film’
00:00:23:00 roadsign ‘Port Campbell National Park’ followed by views from the ocean cliffs including the Twelve Apostles
00:01:52:00 an old grave with an engraved headstone for members of the Carmichael family followed by dramatic views out over the roiling sea
00:05:46:00 the Fletcher Jones headquarters building in Warrnambool, Victoria
00:05:49:00 the ‘hawkers wagon’ emblazoned with information on history of Fletcher Jones as ‘painstaking tailors’
00:05:55:00 views around the grounds of the Fletcher Jones headquarters
00:06:45:00 old boats and sailing ships in dry dock possibly at Flagstaff Hill maritime museum, Warrnambool
00:07:40:00 the Lady Bay lighthouse at Flastaff Hill in Warrnambool and views of a canon looking out to sea
00:09:17:00 a distinctive rocky outcrop on a beach
00:09:52:00 looking out over the waterways and beaches of Warrnambool from a higher vantage point followed by some caves and grassy paddocks with grazing sheep
00:10:29:00 title card ‘The End’
00:10:50:00 title cards ‘A Walkabout Film’ and ‘National Parks of the S.E.’
00:11:15:00 roadsign ‘Mount Richmond National Park’ follwed by close-ups of wildflowers
00:12:03:00 a car with gear packed on the roofrack
00:12:14:00 sign ‘Discovery Bay Coastal Park National Parks Service’
00:14:40:00 bee-keeping
00:14:49:00 walking up a steep sand dune and down again; views of the dunes and beach; pelicans on the water; views of the sea and beaches
00:15:49:00 fishing and a child runs across the frame in ‘gumboots’
00:15:55:00 sign ‘Lower Glenelg National Park’ and ‘Glenelg River’, a large river or lagoon, wildflowers and sea birds
00:17:08:00 sunset over the sea
00:18:57:00 boathouses and small boats on old jettys
00:19:07:00 sign ‘State Border South Australia’
00:19:35:00 jetty and motor boat
00:19:57:00 farmland with old buildings and a windmill
00:21:01:00 looking out from the rocky shore
00:21:30:00 old entry signs ‘Clarke Park’ followed by ‘Dingley Dell’ which is the historic home of one of Australia’s most famous poets, Adam Lindsay Gordon, and views of the cottage in which he lived

The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is made up of two films. The first captures the dramatic coastline of the ‘Shipwreck Coast’ in the west of Victoria. It also features the ‘Fletcher Jones’ (clothing manufacturers) at Warrnambool including the ‘Silver Ball’ water tower designed by Ralph Jones, engineer and eldest son of owner David Fletcher Jones. Erected in 1967 as part of the Pleasant Hill factory’s extensive fire protection system, the water tower was state heritage listed, along with other aspects of the Pleasant Hill site, in August 2006.

The second film features Victorian National parks.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 7]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film captures a group trip by tourist bus, four wheel drive vehicles and truck around the ‘Gulf Country’. The Gulf Country is the region of woodland and savanna grassland surrounding the Gulf of Carpentaria in north western Queensland and parts of the Northern Territory, Australia.

We see many dirt roads and sandy tracks so that we see both a tourist bus and four wheel drive vehicles being dug out of the sand. As always, Wallace includes close-ups of any flora and fauna that catch
his eye along the way.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Gulf Country’, ‘A WHC Film’
00:01:15:00 sign for ‘Four Wheel Drive’.
00:01:21:00 a large lorry style truck travelling ahead on dirt road.
00:01:31:00 digging a vehicle out of sand on a track.
00:02:30:00 tourist bus being hauled from the sandy track by a truck.
00:03:42:00 particularly colourful bird in a tree.
00:03:57:00 people in a small boat catching fish.
00:04:55:00 a row of tents for camping lined up along a riverbank.
00:07:45:00 close up of a blackened ‘billy can’ set over a fire and then a wider shot of a group of picnic-goers.
00:08:09:00 a woman in an example of a 1970s style ‘halter-neck’ top.
00:08:32:00 animal footprints in the dust followed by a large snake making progress through the grass
00:09:14:00 large truck and bus with baggage loaded on roof travel down a dusty road
00:09:57:00 cattle in stockyards
00:10:27:00 wetlands and wildflowers
00:11:45:00 swimming in a river
00:11:53:00 a close-up of a spider in the middle of a large web wit the blue of the river in the background
00:12:53:00 title card ‘The End’

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 23]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film captures the scenery around the You Yangs and other nature spots in Victoria. Wallace includes lots of close-ups of wildflowers along the way as well as old farm machinery, some lovely old buildings, monuments, rocky outcrops, scrub, trees and sky.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:02:35:00 walkers in the scrub
00:03:22:00 a koala peers at the camera
00:03:36:00 remains of a wooden sluice in a creek that may have been an old gold mining site
00:03:50:00 hearing instructions or a talk at a campsite with a fire
00:04:45:00 setting off on a walk through farm lands and gates
00:05:05:00 sheep run across a paddock and a swirling, foaming river spilling across rocks with spectacular waterfalls
00:06:52:00 collecting driftwood by the dramatic river
00:07:18:00 scenes showing the treacherous route for walking the banks of the swollen, fast flowing river
00:09:54:00 jumping from rock to rock over a creek
00:10:18:00 using logs to cross a creek
00:10:27:00 hikers walk up a long grassy hill with some sheep running by, toward a gravel quarry or storage area
00:11:03:00 looking for rock specimens or stones in the gravel
00:11:13:00 some hikers stop for a chat before scrambling over a rocky part of the hills
00:12:15:00 flowers, mushrooms and toadstools
00:13:08:00 a long lizard close-up followed by a centipede
00:14:40:00 a trickling creek before scenes of rushing waters in a small creek
00:15:50:00 country roads
00:16:29:00 filming a photographer taking pictures of wildflowers followed by close-ups of flowers
00:18:16:00 several wild orchids
00:19:15:00 a campfire at night
00:19:44:00 stone monument with a plaque that reads ‘Erected 1951. In memory of the pioneers of Steiglitz and the discovery of gold 1851 - 1853’
00:19:50:00 the the lovely brick Steiglitz Court House among gumtrees, a plain but lovely old house across the road and a farm cottage next to an old chimney that could be all that remains of an earlier house
00:20:33:00 a flock of ducks or geese
00:20:45:00 an old brick fireplace surrounded by the trees and bushes that have overtaken it, followed by several ageing weatherboard buildings
00:21:23:00 sign ‘Walking track to Flinders Peak’ (in the You Yangs, Victoria) followed by views from a higher vantage point in the You Yangs
00:22:19:00 views of jutting rocks and outcrops and some of the farmland beyond the You Yangs
00:23:48:00 plaque for ‘Matthew Flinders RN who stood on this rock to survey the bay’

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 31]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 88m film.

This film showcases Wilson’s Promontory in Victoria, in particular the coastlines and islands as the filming is done from on board a motorsail boat. Wallace captures the dramatic rocky formations of the shores of the Promontory as well as fishing off the boat and preparing the catch. The fish is likely to be local favourite, ‘King George Whiting’.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:08:00 a woman takes photographs from the deck of a moving ‘motorsail’ boat
00:00:45:00 a mountainous island comes into view followed by views of rocky shorelines and cliffs
00:03:03:00 a boat crosses the water
00:03:18:00 fishing off the back of the moving boat
00:05:35:00 seagulls sitting on the wavy water surface
00:05:51:00 spectacular rocks on the shoreline
00:06:17:00 fish catch in a crate and struggling to remove the fish hook
00:07:10:00 views from the boat looking toward the rocky shoreline
00:08:40:00 lighthouse at South East Point built in 1859
00:10:55:00 waterbirds standing on shoreline rocks
00:11:18:00 gutting and filleting fish on old wooden crates in the stern of the boat
00:11:26:00 a speed boat passes by

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 29]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is about a trip around North Queensland to locations such as Townsville and National Parks. Wallace films the wonderful brolga water birds of the title but also captures the dramatic Wallaman Falls in Girringun Park, which is Australia’s highest permanent single drop waterfall, and the Little Crystal Creek Bridge on Mount Spec Rd in Paluma Range National Park. The bridge and Mt Spec Road are of particular interest as both are listed heritage sites on the Queensland Heritage Register and were constructed during the Great Depression in the 1930s using mostly unskilled labour and with the application of ‘Unemployment Relief Scheme’ funds. Mt Spec Road remains substantially intact throughout the 18km of its length and demonstrates an extensive and now uncommon use of concrete arch culverts, dry stone walling and stone-paved gutters. Also, the very picturesque bridge is the only identified concrete arch bridge dressed with stone remaining in service in Queensland.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Where Brolgas Dance’, ‘Filmed by WHC’
00:00:27:00 the ‘Air Cloud’ tour boat moored at a pier
00:00:32:00 looking out from the pier over a lake or river followed by boats sitting on sand and mud when the tide is out and remains of old jettys
00:01:03:00 views of boats moored at jettys and piers
00:02:09:00 sunflowers in the foreground of mountains
00:02:27:00 the ‘Burdekin Bridge’ rail and car bridge in Queensland
00:03:38:00 sugar cane, wetlands and lily pads and roaming cattle
00:04:13:00 a large spider web in the wetlands complete with black spider in the middle
00:04:30:00 driving through Townsville in Queensland, and past the ‘T&G Building’
00:06:13:00 views of brolgas standing in grass and flying overhead
00:07:52:00 signs for ‘Mt Spec National Park’ and ‘Little Crystal Creek’
00:07:59:00 views of the Little Crystal Creek Bridge and the creek itself with its lovely rocky banks
00:08:24:00 a roadside picnic and exploring under the bridge
00:08:54:00 sign for ‘McClelland Bridge’ followed by scenic views of mountains and waterways
00:10:06:00 driving through the rainforest
00:10:48:00 views of the dramatic Wallaman Falls
00:11:01:00 sign for the Falls with facts and information for campers
00:11:34:00 sightseers at a lookout
00:12:03:00 a small modest road bridge
00:12:16:00 title ‘The End’

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 18]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film, titled ‘Papua New Guinea May - June 1961; No.1’, shows landscapes, seascapes, vegetation, people, villages, boats, roads, cars and other infrastructure of Papua New Guinea. It includes aerial footage of sea, forest, and mountains, and scenes of the (former) Royal Australian Navy base HMAS Tarangau at Manus Island.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:20:00 activities at a small airport
00:00:43:00 ‘Trans Australian Airlines’ (TAA) seaplane
00:02:12:00 luggage being manually loaded onto Ansett Australia plane by local staff.
00:02:36:00 passengers file past local staff wearing distinctive ‘Anset AAA’ waist-to-calf tunics
00:03:21:00 brief glimpses of a rugby match
00:07:47:00 outdoor classroom with young students at work
00:10:27:00 group of men constructing (or repairing) a traditional village building
00:14:04:00 woman preparing coconut with a large knife
00:16:53:00 large ship (probably one of the Royal Australian Navy) in port
00:17:06:00 small monument bearing sign ‘Tarangau’ (Royal Australlian Navy base HMAS Tarangau, commissioned 1950)
00:17:26:00 sailors in white uniform lined-up on deck
00:17:37:00 ship moves off from port
00:20:52:00 a food market with many people
00:27:39:00 distinctive three-sailed boat

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 32]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film shows a trip made by the ‘Walkabouters’ to the Wyperfeld National Park in northwestern Victoria. Wallace as usual focuses on the landscape, flora and fauna and in doing so, captures the arid beauty of the region. A highlight of the film is the usually hard to find malleefowl (or hen), an endangered bird in Victoria that Wallace films in its dry, inland scrub habitat. The malleefowl is a mound builder which, unlike any other birds in Australia, uses its large strong feet to create enormous mounds of soil in which their eggs are incubated, heated by the sun or rotting leaves.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:05:00 titles, ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Wyperfeld’, ‘Filmed by WHC’
00:00:33:00 a paddock of grazing sheep
00:00:46:00 a sign for ‘Wyperfeld National Park National Parks Service’ and some wildflowers
00:01:27:00 a malleefowl at work on top of its mound, followed by more wildflowers
00:02:08:00 emus
00:02:28:00 chopping fallen logs
00:02:58:00 a brown beetle
00:03:12:00 walkers on a walking track in the Park
00:03:28:00 a bird in a eucalypt (gumtree)
00:04:01:00 sandy terrain and wildflowers
00:05:34:00 a scary looking banksia plant seed pod close-up followed by more examples of banksia pods
00:06:17:00 the ‘Walkerbouters’ itinerary on a black board, including daily destinations and when to carry lunch
00:06:30:00 views of the landscape around the Park and what is likely to be a variety of blue-tongue lizard
00:08:23:00 the walkers’ campsite and another blackboard itinerary notice
00:09:33:00 the walkers rest on a large, fallen tree log
00:11:05:00 birds flying overhead
00:12:38:00 a particularly wide trunk eucalypt (gumtree) tree in the Park attracts the walkers’ attention
00:13:38:00 sandy dune-like mounds throughout the Park
00:14:18:00 walking under what appears to be old tea tree branches and possibly saltbush among more close-ups of wildflowers
